title: More Intuition-Building On Non-Empirical Science: Three Stories
summary:
Key ideas
- Two theories can make identical predictions but differ in other ways that are important to consider.
- Choosing the simpler theory among identical ones requires understanding of philosophy.
- The number of entities in a theory is not the only factor to consider when determining which theory is simpler.

Key learnings
- Making accurate predictions is not the only important factor when evaluating a theory.
- Determining which of two identical theories is simpler can require a detailed understanding of philosophy and the assumptions underlying each theory.
- The number of entities in a theory is not the only factor to consider when determining which theory is simpler.

Key questions
- How can one determine which theory is simpler among two that make identical predictions?
- What are some examples of theories that make identical predictions but differ in other important ways?
- How can the two previous morals be applied to other areas of science or philosophy?
